title: 115_s1185
content: The Act titled "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" includes amendments related to anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking. The Act "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" introduces amendments regarding anti-straw purchasing and firearms trafficking, including definitions for terms like 'crime of violence' and 'drug trafficking crime' in Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" introduces amendments related to firearms trafficking and anti-straw purchasing. It prohibits individuals (excluding licensed importers, manufacturers, collectors, or dealers) from knowingly purchasing firearms in interstate or foreign commerce. The act defines terms like 'Federal crime of terrorism' and 'purchase' to include receiving firearms through pledge, pawn, or consignment. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits individuals from purchasing firearms in interstate or foreign commerce if they know or have reasonable cause to believe that the recipient is under indictment for a crime punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year, a fugitive from justice, or an unlawful user of controlled substances. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits individuals from purchasing firearms if they have certain disqualifying factors, such as being adjudicated as mentally defective, committed to a mental institution, an illegal alien, dishonorably discharged from the Armed Forces, renounced U.S. citizenship, or other specified conditions. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits individuals from purchasing firearms if they have certain disqualifying factors, such as renouncing U.S. citizenship or being subject to a court order restraining them from harassing, stalking, or threatening an intimate partner or child. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits individuals from purchasing firearms if they have certain disqualifying factors, such as being convicted of a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence or intending to sell the firearm to someone who is not a citizen or lawful permanent resident of the United States. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" imposes penalties for violating the prohibition on purchasing firearms for illegal activities, including fines and imprisonment up to 15 years. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" imposes penalties for purchasing firearms for illegal activities, with imprisonment up to 25 years. Exceptions include lawful purchases for gifts, raffles, gratuities, bonuses, and awards. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits the transfer of firearms to individuals prohibited by law. It is illegal to ship or receive firearms if the recipient would violate federal or state laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. The "Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017" prohibits receiving firearms in violation of federal or state laws punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. Violators face fines, imprisonment up to 15 years, or both. Forfeiture of property is mandated for those convicted of violations. The court orders forfeiture of any proceeds or property used in committing a violation of section 932 or 933. Defendants who profit from these offenses may face fines. The fines for offenses under section 932 or 933 may be the greater of the authorized fine or twice the gross profits of the offense. Amendments are made to various sections of the United States Code to include these offenses. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend its guidelines to increase penalties for offenses related to straw purchases and firearms trafficking, particularly for individuals without significant criminal histories. The Commission will review and update its guidelines to impose higher penalties on individuals affiliated with criminal organizations under sections 932 or 933 of title 18, United States Code. Additionally, a technical amendment will be made to chapter 44 of title 18. Amendments to section 922(D) include provisions on straw purchasing of firearms, trafficking in firearms, and forfeiture and fines. Amendments to section 922(d) of title 18, United States Code, now include new provisions regarding the sale or disposal of firearms or ammunition to prohibited persons, as well as intentions to commit federal crimes of terrorism, violence, or drug trafficking offenses. The subsection prohibits exporting firearms or ammunition in violation of the law, except for sales to licensed individuals or those granted relief from disabilities under specific sections. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(A) and 924(D) of title 18, United States Code involve fines and imprisonment for knowingly violating subsections related to firearms. Additionally, AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(H) are made. SEC. 6. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(H) involve fines and imprisonment for knowingly receiving or transferring firearms or ammunition for criminal activities, including terrorism, violence, drug trafficking, and other specified crimes. The maximum imprisonment term is 15 years, and the sentence does not run concurrently with other related offenses. AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(K) AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 924(K): Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include harsh penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition into or out of the United States with intent to engage in criminal activities such as drug trafficking, terrorism, or violence. Offenders could face fines, imprisonment for up to 15 years, or both. The amended Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, imposes severe penalties for smuggling firearms or ammunition with intent to engage in criminal activities like drug trafficking, terrorism, or violence. Offenders could face fines, imprisonment for up to 15 years, or both under the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act or Federal crime of terrorism. SEC. 8 prohibits the transfer of firearms to drug cartel agents unless continuously monitored. SEC. 9 clarifies that the Act does not establish a federal firearm registration system.
